email_content:
Dear Mark,

Thank you for your follow-up and for the opportunity to clarify how Union Trust Bank handles customer disputes. Below is a concise, up-to-date overview that addresses the three areas you asked about and highlights the latest improvements to our programme.

1. How a customer initiates a dispute
• Any branch, our 24-hour Contact Centre (1-800-UTB-HELP), secure Online Banking portal (Complaints ▸ New Dispute) or written letter to the Customer Advocacy Department.
• We acknowledge every complaint within five (5) business days, provide a unique case reference and assign a dedicated case manager who serves as the single point of contact.

2. Expected processing times & milestones
• Standard cases – investigation and final response within 30 calendar days (reduced from 35 days in July 2024).
• Complex cases – may extend to 60 days; if so, the customer receives a written interim update at Day 30 explaining the delay and a revised timeline.
• Card-transaction disputes – if investigation is likely to exceed 10 business days, we issue provisional credit by Day 10 in accordance with card-scheme rules.
• A formal resolution letter is sent at closure summarising findings, any account adjustments and next-step options.

3. Documentation typically requested
• Dispute/chargeback form (digital or PDF).
• Account statement showing the transaction(s) in question.
• Supporting evidence (receipts, invoices, e-mails or chat transcripts with the merchant, screenshots, etc.).
• Government-issued photo ID if the customer has not previously verified identity through our digital channel.

Recent enhancements
• Q4-2021: Secure upload portal & electronic signature acceptance introduced (now used in 97 % of submissions).
• Jan 2024: Mobile self-service tracking tool launched, giving customers real-time status updates and the ability to add evidence from their phone.
• July 2024: Target timeframe lowered to 30 days; average resolution time in 2024 was 22.6 days with 94 % of cases closed inside the target.

Escalation avenues
• Internal: A customer may request a secondary review by our Dispute Resolution Committee, chaired by a senior vice-president not involved in the original decision.
• External: If still dissatisfied, they may contact the Financial Services Ombudsman or (for card disputes) the relevant card-scheme arbitration panel. Full contact details are provided in every resolution letter.

I hope this answers your questions, but please let me know if you need any additional data points, anonymised case studies or would like to schedule a call.

Best regards,

Jane Doe
Senior Manager, Customer Advocacy
Union Trust Bank
